[[6]](#cite_note-Barrett2007-8) [[7]](#cite_note-Wang2013-9) [[8]](#cite_note-rank-10) There is a range of acupuncture variants which originated in different philosophies, [[9]](#cite_note-Peñas2010-11) and techniques vary depending on the country in which it is performed. However, it can be divided into two main foundational philosophical applications and approaches; the first form being the modern standardized form called [eight principles](/wiki/Eight_principles) TCM and the second an older system that is based on the ancient [Daoist](/wiki/Daoist) [wuxing](/wiki/Wuxing_(Chinese_philosophy)), better known as the five elements or phases in the West. [[10]](#cite_note-Ernst2006-12) [[11]](#cite_note-13) [[12]](#cite_note-14) Acupuncture is most often used to attempt pain relief, [[13]](#cite_note-Ernst_2011-15) [[14]](#cite_note-NCCAM2010-16) though acupuncturists say that it can also be used for a wide range of other conditions. Acupuncture is generally used only in combination with other forms of treatment. [[15]](#cite_note-Hutchinson2012-17) The global acupuncture market was worth US$24.55 billion in 2017. The market was led by Europe with a 32.7% share, followed by Asia-Pacific with a 29.4% share and the Americas with a 25.3% share. It was estimated in 2021 that the industry would reach a market size of $55bn by 2023. [[16]](#cite_note-18) The conclusions of trials and [systematic reviews](/wiki/Systematic_review) of acupuncture generally provide no good evidence of benefit, which suggests that it is not an effective method of healthcare. [[17]](#cite_note-sys0-19) [[18]](#cite_note-sys-20) Acupuncture is generally safe when done by appropriately trained practitioners using clean needle technique and single-use needles. [[19]](#cite_note-Xu_S-21) [[20]](#cite_note-nciacupuncture-22) When properly delivered, it has a low rate of mostly minor [adverse effects](/wiki/Adverse_effects). [[3]](#cite_note-Adams_2011-5) [[19]](#cite_note-Xu_S-21) When accidents and infections do occur, they are associated with neglect on the part of the practitioner, particularly in the application of [sterile techniques](/wiki/Asepsis). [[13]](#cite_note-Ernst_2011-15) [[20]](#cite_note-nciacupuncture-22) A review conducted in 2013 stated that reports of infection transmission increased significantly in the preceding decade. [[21]](#cite_note-Gnatta2013-23) The most frequently reported adverse events were [pneumothorax](/wiki/Pneumothorax) and infections. [[13]](#cite_note-Ernst_2011-15) Since serious adverse events continue to be reported, it is recommended that acupuncturists be trained sufficiently to reduce the risk. [[13]](#cite_note-Ernst_2011-15) Scientific investigation has not found any [histological](/wiki/Histology) or [physiological](/wiki/Physiology) evidence for traditional Chinese concepts such as [qi](/wiki/Qi), [meridians](/wiki/Meridian_(Chinese_medicine)), and acupuncture points, [[c]](#cite_note-SinghErnst2008-27) [[25]](#cite_note-Ahn2008-28) and many modern practitioners no longer support the existence of life force energy (qi) or meridians, which was a major part of early belief systems. [[9]](#cite_note-Peñas2010-11) [[26]](#cite_note-Mann2000-29) [[27]](#cite_note-Williams2013-30) Acupuncture is believed to have originated around 100 BC in China, around the time The Inner Classic of Huang Di ( [Huangdi Neijing](/wiki/Huangdi_Neijing)) was published, [[28]](#cite_note-White-Ernst-31) though some experts suggest it could have been practiced earlier. [[10]](#cite_note-Ernst2006-12) Over time, conflicting claims and belief systems emerged about the effect of lunar, celestial and earthly cycles, [yin and yang](/wiki/Yin_and_yang) energies, and a body's "rhythm" on the effectiveness of treatment. [[29]](#cite_note-Prioreschi2004-32) Acupuncture fluctuated in popularity in China due to changes in the country's political leadership and the preferential use of rationalism or scientific medicine. [[28]](#cite_note-White-Ernst-31) Acupuncture spread first to Korea in the 6th century AD, then to Japan through medical missionaries, [[30]](#cite_note-abc-33) and then to Europe, beginning with France. [[28]](#cite_note-White-Ernst-31) In the 20th century, as it spread to the United States and Western countries, spiritual elements of acupuncture that conflicted with scientific knowledge were sometimes abandoned in favor of simply tapping needles into acupuncture points. [[28]](#cite_note-White-Ernst-31) [[31]](#cite_note-Porter_2013_p._403-34) [[32]](#cite_note-Jackson_2011_p._610-35) Clinical practice Acupuncture is a form of alternative medicine. [[2]](#cite_note-Berman2010-4) It is used most commonly for pain relief, [[13]](#cite_note-Ernst_2011-15) [[14]](#cite_note-NCCAM2010-16) though it is also used to treat a wide range of conditions. Acupuncture is generally only used in combination with other forms of treatment. [[15]](#cite_note-Hutchinson2012-17) For example, the [American Society of Anesthesiologists](/wiki/American_Society_of_Anesthesiologists) states it may be considered in the treatment for nonspecific, noninflammatory low back pain only in conjunction with conventional therapy. [[33]](#cite_note-36) Acupuncture is the insertion of thin needles into the skin. [[3]](#cite_note-Adams_2011-5) According to the [Mayo Foundation for Medical Education and Research](/wiki/Mayo_Foundation_for_Medical_Education_and_Research) (Mayo Clinic), a typical session entails lying still while approximately five to twenty needles are inserted; for the majority of cases, the needles will be left in place for ten to twenty minutes. [[34]](#cite_note-mayo2012-37) It can be associated with the application of heat, pressure, or [laser light](/wiki/Laser_light). [[3]](#cite_note-Adams_2011-5) Classically, acupuncture is individualized and based on philosophy and intuition, and not on scientific research. [[35]](#cite_note-38) There is also a [non-invasive](/wiki/Invasiveness_of_surgical_procedures#Non-invasive_procedure) therapy developed in early 20th century Japan using an elaborate set of instruments other than needles for the treatment of children (shnishin or shnihari). [[36]](#cite_note-39) [[37]](#cite_note-40) Clinical practice varies depending on the country. [[10]](#cite_note-Ernst2006-12) [[38]](#cite_note-Dummies-41) A comparison of the average number of patients treated per hour found significant differences between China (10) and the United States (1.2). [[39]](#cite_note-42) [Chinese herbs](/wiki/Chinese_herbs) are often used. [[40]](#cite_note-Sherman-43) There is a diverse range of acupuncture approaches, involving different philosophies. [[9]](#cite_note-Peñas2010-11) Although various different techniques of acupuncture practice have emerged, the method used in traditional Chinese medicine (TCM) seems to be the most widely adopted in the US. [[2]](#cite_note-Berman2010-4) Traditional acupuncture involves needle insertion, [moxibustion](/wiki/Moxibustion), and [cupping therapy](/wiki/Cupping_therapy), [[19]](#cite_note-Xu_S-21) and may be accompanied by other procedures such as feeling the [pulse](/wiki/Radial_pulse) and other parts of the body and examining the tongue. [[2]](#cite_note-Berman2010-4) Traditional acupuncture involves the belief that a "life force" ( [qi](/wiki/Qi)) circulates within the body in lines called meridians. [[41]](#cite_note-NHS-44) The main methods practiced in the UK are TCM and Western medical acupuncture. [[42]](#cite_note-Wheway2012-45) The term Western medical acupuncture is used to indicate an adaptation of TCM-based acupuncture which focuses less on TCM. [[41]](#cite_note-NHS-44) [[43]](#cite_note-WhiteCummings2008-46) The Western medical acupuncture approach involves using acupuncture after a medical diagnosis. [[41]](#cite_note-NHS-44) Limited research has compared the contrasting acupuncture systems used in various countries for determining different acupuncture points and thus there is no defined standard for acupuncture points. [[44]](#cite_note-Millers2014-47) In traditional acupuncture, the acupuncturist decides which points to treat by observing and questioning the patient to make a diagnosis according to the tradition used. In TCM, the four diagnostic methods are: inspection, auscultation and olfaction, inquiring, and palpation. Inspection focuses on the face and particularly on the tongue, including analysis of the tongue size, shape, tension, color and coating, and the absence or presence of teeth marks around the edge. [[45]](#cite_note-Cheng1987-48) Auscultation and olfaction involve listening for particular sounds such as wheezing, and observing body odor. [[45]](#cite_note-Cheng1987-48) Inquiring involves focusing on the "seven inquiries": chills and fever; perspiration; appetite, [menses](/wiki/Menses) and [leukorrhea](/wiki/Leukorrhea). [[45]](#cite_note-Cheng1987-48) Palpation is focusing on feeling the body for tender "A-shi" points and feeling the pulse. [[45]](#cite_note-Cheng1987-48) Needles The most common mechanism of stimulation of acupuncture points employs penetration of the skin by thin metal needles, which are manipulated manually or the needle may be further stimulated by electrical stimulation (electroacupuncture). [[2]](#cite_note-Berman2010-4) Acupuncture needles are typically made of stainless steel, making them flexible and preventing them from rusting or breaking. [[46]](#cite_note-Hicks2005-49) Needles are usually disposed of after each use to prevent contamination. [[46]](#cite_note-Hicks2005-49) Reusable needles when used should be sterilized between applications. [[46]](#cite_note-Hicks2005-49) [[47]](#cite_note-50) In many areas, only sterile, single-use acupuncture needles are allowed, including the State of California, USA. [[48]](#cite_note-51) Needles vary in length between 13 and 130 millimetres (0.51 and 5.12 in), with shorter needles used near the face and eyes, and longer needles in areas with thicker tissues; needle diameters vary from 0.16 mm (0.006 in) to 0.46 mm (0.018 in), [[49]](#cite_note-Aung116-52) with thicker needles used on more robust patients. Thinner needles may be flexible and require tubes for insertion. The tip of the needle should not be made too sharp to prevent breakage, although blunt needles cause more pain. [[50]](#cite_note-FCA-53) Apart from the usual filiform needle, other needle types include three-edged needles and the Nine Ancient Needles. [[49]](#cite_note-Aung116-52) Japanese acupuncturists use extremely thin needles that are used superficially, sometimes without penetrating the skin, and surrounded by a guide tube (a 17th-century invention adopted in China and the West). Korean acupuncture uses copper needles and has a greater focus on the hand. [[38]](#cite_note-Dummies-41) Needling technique Insertion The skin is sterilized and needles are inserted, frequently with a plastic guide tube. Needles may be manipulated in various ways, including spinning, flicking, or moving up and down relative to the skin. Since most pain is felt in the superficial layers of the skin, a quick insertion of the needle is recommended. [[51]](#cite_note-Aung2007-54) Often the needles are stimulated by hand in order to cause a dull, localized, aching sensation that is called de qi, as well as "needle grasp," a tugging feeling felt by the acupuncturist and generated by a mechanical interaction between the needle and skin. [[2]](#cite_note-Berman2010-4) Acupuncture can be painful. [[52]](#cite_note-55) The skill level of the acupuncturist may influence how painful the needle insertion is, and a sufficiently skilled practitioner may be able to insert the needles without causing any pain. [[51]](#cite_note-Aung2007-54) a claimed sensation of numbness, distension, or electrical tingling at the needling site. If these sensations are not observed then inaccurate location of the [acupoint](/wiki/Acupoint), improper depth of needle insertion, inadequate manual manipulation, are blamed. If de-qi is not immediately observed upon needle insertion, various manual manipulation techniques are often applied to promote it (such as "plucking", "shaking" or "trembling"). [[53]](#cite_note-AungChen2007-56) Once de-qi is observed, techniques might be used which attempt to "influence" the de-qi; for example, by certain manipulation the de-qi can allegedly be conducted from the needling site towards more distant sites of the body. Other techniques aim at "tonifying" ( [Chinese](/wiki/Simplified_Chinese_characters): qi. [[53]](#cite_note-AungChen2007-56) The former techniques are used in [deficiency](/wiki/Traditional_Chinese_medicine#Eight_principles_of_diagnosis) patterns, the latter in excess patterns. [[53]](#cite_note-AungChen2007-56) De qi is more important in Chinese acupuncture, while Western and Japanese patients may not consider it a necessary part of the treatment. [[38]](#cite_note-Dummies-41) Related practices [Acupressure](/wiki/Acupressure), a non-invasive form of bodywork, uses physical pressure applied to acupressure points by the hand or elbow, or with various devices. [[54]](#cite_note-57) - Acupuncture is often accompanied by [moxibustion](/wiki/Moxibustion), the burning of cone-shaped preparations of moxa (made from dried [mugwort](/wiki/Mugwort)) on or near the skin, often but not always near or on an acupuncture point. Traditionally, acupuncture was used to treat [acute conditions](/wiki/Acute_(medicine))while moxibustion was used for [chronic diseases](/wiki/Chronic_(medicine)). Moxibustion could be direct (the cone was placed directly on the skin and allowed to burn the skin, producing a blister and eventually a scar), or indirect (either a cone of moxa was placed on a slice of garlic, ginger or other vegetable, or a cylinder of moxa was held above the skin, close enough to either warm or burn it). [[17]](#cite_note-sys0-19) For [Science-Based Medicine](/wiki/Science-Based_Medicine), [Steven Novella](/wiki/Steven_Novella) wrote that the overall pattern of evidence was reminiscent of that for [homeopathy](/wiki/Homeopathy), compatible with the hypothesis that most, if not all, benefits were due to the [placebo effect](/wiki/Placebo_effect), and strongly suggestive that acupuncture had no beneficial therapeutic effects at all. [[18]](#cite_note-sys-20) Research methodology and challenges Sham acupuncture and research It is difficult but not impossible to design rigorous research trials for acupuncture. [[70]](#cite_note-White2001-73) [[71]](#cite_note-74) Due to acupuncture's invasive nature, one of the major challenges in [efficacy](/wiki/Efficacy#Medicine) research is in the design of an appropriate placebo [control group](/wiki/Control_group). [[72]](#cite_note-Ersnt-2007-75) [[73]](#cite_note-Johnson2006-76) For efficacy studies to determine whether acupuncture has specific effects, "sham" forms of acupuncture where the patient, practitioner, and analyst are [blinded](/wiki/Blind_experiment) seem the most acceptable approach. [[70]](#cite_note-White2001-73) Sham acupuncture uses non-penetrating needles or needling at non-acupuncture points, [[74]](#cite_note-77) e.g. inserting needles on meridians not related to the specific condition being studied, or in places not associated with meridians. [[75]](#cite_note-Urruela2012-78) The under-performance of acupuncture in such trials may indicate that therapeutic effects are due entirely to non-specific effects, or that the sham treatments are not inert, or that systematic protocols yield less than optimal treatment. [[76]](#cite_note-Langevin2011-79) [[77]](#cite_note-80) A 2014 [review](/wiki/Review_article) in [Nature Reviews Cancer](/wiki/Nature_Reviews_Cancer) found that "contrary to the claimed mechanism of redirecting the flow of qi through meridians, researchers usually find that it generally does not matter where the needles are inserted, how often (that is, no dose-response effect is observed), or even if needles are actually inserted. In other words, 'sham' or 'placebo' acupuncture generally produces the same effects as 'real' acupuncture and, in some cases, does better." [[78]](#cite_note-Gorski2014-81) A 2013 meta-analysis found little evidence that the effectiveness of acupuncture on pain (compared to sham) was modified by the location of the needles, the number of needles used, the experience or technique of the practitioner, or by the circumstances of the sessions. [[79]](#cite_note-MacPherson2013-82) The same analysis also suggested that the number of needles and sessions is important, as greater numbers improved the outcomes of acupuncture compared to non-acupuncture controls. [[79]](#cite_note-MacPherson2013-82) There has been little systematic investigation of which components of an acupuncture session may be important for any therapeutic effect, including needle placement and depth, type and intensity of stimulation, and number of needles used. [[76]](#cite_note-Langevin2011-79) The research seems to suggest that needles do not need to stimulate the traditionally specified acupuncture points or penetrate the skin to attain an anticipated effect (e.g. psychosocial factors). [[2]](#cite_note-Berman2010-4) A response to "sham" acupuncture in osteoarthritis may be used in the elderly, but placebos have usually been regarded as deception and thus unethical. [[80]](#cite_note-Cherniack2010-83) However, some physicians and ethicists have suggested circumstances for applicable uses for placebos such as it might present a theoretical advantage of an inexpensive treatment without adverse reactions or interactions with drugs or other medications. [[80]](#cite_note-Cherniack2010-83) As the evidence for most types of alternative medicine such as acupuncture is far from strong, the use of alternative medicine in regular healthcare can present an ethical question. [[81]](#cite_note-Posadzki2012-84) Using the principles of [evidence-based medicine](/wiki/Evidence-based_medicine) to research acupuncture is controversial, and has produced different results. [[72]](#cite_note-Ersnt-2007-75) Some research suggests acupuncture can alleviate pain but the majority of research suggests that acupuncture's effects are mainly due to placebo. [[10]](#cite_note-Ernst2006-12) Evidence suggests that any benefits of acupuncture are short-lasting. [[82]](#cite_note-Wang-2008-85) There is insufficient evidence to support use of acupuncture compared to [mainstream medical treatments](/wiki/Medicine). [[83]](#cite_note-GoldmanSchafer2015-86) Acupuncture is not better than mainstream treatment in the long term. [[75]](#cite_note-Urruela2012-78) The use of acupuncture has been criticized owing to there being little scientific evidence for explicit effects, or the mechanisms for its supposed effectiveness, for any condition that is discernible from placebo. [[78]](#cite_note-Gorski2014-81) Acupuncture has been called 'theatrical placebo', [[58]](#cite_note-Colquhoun2013-61) and [David Gorski](/wiki/David_Gorski) argues that when acupuncture proponents advocate 'harnessing of placebo effects' or work on developing 'meaningful placebos', they essentially concede it is little more than that. [[78]](#cite_note-Gorski2014-81) Publication bias [Publication bias](/wiki/Publication_bias) is cited as a concern in the reviews of [randomized controlled trials](/wiki/Randomized_controlled_trial) of acupuncture. [[58]](#cite_note-Colquhoun2013-61) [[84]](#cite_note-Lee2006-87) [[85]](#cite_note-Tang1999-88) A 1998 review of studies on acupuncture found that trials originating in China, Japan, Hong Kong, and Taiwan were uniformly favourable to acupuncture, as were ten out of eleven studies conducted in Russia. [[86]](#cite_note-Vickers1998-89) A 2011 assessment of the quality of randomized controlled trials on traditional Chinese medicine, including acupuncture, concluded that the methodological quality of most such trials (including randomization, experimental control, and blinding) was generally poor, particularly for trials published in Chinese journals (though the quality of acupuncture trials was better than the trials testing traditional Chinese medicine remedies). [[87]](#cite_note-He-2011-90) The study also found that trials published in non-Chinese journals tended to be of higher quality. [[87]](#cite_note-He-2011-90) Chinese authors use more Chinese studies, which have been demonstrated to be uniformly positive. [[88]](#cite_note-Ernst2012-91) A 2012 review of 88 systematic reviews of acupuncture published in Chinese journals found that less than half of these reviews reported testing for publication bias, and that the majority of these reviews were published in journals with [impact factors](/wiki/Impact_factor) of zero. [[89]](#cite_note-92) A 2015 study comparing pre-registered records of acupuncture trials with their published results found that it was uncommon for such trials to be registered before the trial began. This study also found that selective reporting of results and changing outcome measures to obtain statistically significant results was common in this literature. [[90]](#cite_note-93) Scientist and journalist [Steven Salzberg](/wiki/Steven_Salzberg) identifies acupuncture and Chinese medicine generally as a focus for "fake medical journals" such as the [Journal of Acupuncture and Meridian Studies](/wiki/Journal_of_Acupuncture_and_Meridian_Studies) and [Acupuncture in Medicine](/wiki/Acupuncture_in_Medicine). [[91]](#cite_note-94) Safety Adverse events Acupuncture is generally safe when administered by an experienced, appropriately trained practitioner using clean-needle technique and sterile single-use needles. [[20]](#cite_note-nciacupuncture-22) When improperly delivered it can cause adverse effects. [[19]](#cite_note-Xu_S-21) Accidents and infections are associated with infractions of sterile technique or neglect on the part of the practitioner. [[20]](#cite_note-nciacupuncture-22) To reduce the risk of serious adverse events after acupuncture, acupuncturists should be trained sufficiently. [[13]](#cite_note-Ernst_2011-15) A 2009 overview of [Cochrane reviews](/wiki/Cochrane_Collaboration) found acupuncture is not effective for a wide range of conditions. [[92]](#cite_note-Ernst2009-95) People with serious spinal disease, such as cancer or infection, are not good candidates for acupuncture. [[2]](#cite_note-Berman2010-4) [Contraindications](/wiki/Contraindication) to acupuncture (conditions that should not be treated with acupuncture) include coagulopathy disorders (e.g. hemophilia and advanced liver disease), warfarin use, severe psychiatric disorders (e.g. psychosis), and skin infections or skin trauma (e.g. burns). [[2]](#cite_note-Berman2010-4) Further, electroacupuncture should be avoided at the spot of implanted electrical devices (such as pacemakers). [[2]](#cite_note-Berman2010-4) A 2011 systematic review of systematic reviews (internationally and without language restrictions) found that serious complications following acupuncture continue to be reported. [[13]](#cite_note-Ernst_2011-15) Between 2000 and 2009, ninety-five cases of [serious adverse events](/wiki/Serious_adverse_event), including five [deaths](/wiki/Deaths), were reported. [[13]](#cite_note-Ernst_2011-15) Many such events are not inherent to acupuncture but are due to [malpractice](/wiki/Medical_malpractice) of acupuncturists. [[13]](#cite_note-Ernst_2011-15) This might be why such complications have not been reported in surveys of adequately trained acupuncturists. [[13]](#cite_note-Ernst_2011-15) Most such reports originate from Asia, which may reflect the large number of treatments performed there or a relatively higher number of poorly trained Asian acupuncturists. [[13]](#cite_note-Ernst_2011-15) Many serious adverse events were reported from developed countries. [[13]](#cite_note-Ernst_2011-15) These included Australia, Austria, Canada, Croatia, France, Germany, Ireland, the Netherlands, New Zealand, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, the UK, and the US. [[13]](#cite_note-Ernst_2011-15) The number of adverse effects reported from the UK appears particularly unusual, which may indicate less under-reporting in the UK than other countries. [[13]](#cite_note-Ernst_2011-15) Reports included 38 cases of infections and 42 cases of organ trauma. [[13]](#cite_note-Ernst_2011-15) The most frequent adverse events included [pneumothorax](/wiki/Pneumothorax), and [bacterial](/wiki/Bacterial_infection) and [viral infections](/wiki/Viral_infection). [[13]](#cite_note-Ernst_2011-15) A 2013 review found (without restrictions regarding publication date, study type or language) 295 cases of infections; [mycobacterium](/wiki/Mycobacterium) was the [pathogen](/wiki/Pathogen) in at least 96%. [[21]](#cite_note-Gnatta2013-23) Likely sources of infection include towels, hot packs or boiling tank water, and reusing reprocessed needles. [[21]](#cite_note-Gnatta2013-23) Possible sources of infection include contaminated needles, reusing personal needles, a person's skin containing mycobacterium, and reusing needles at various sites in the same person. [[21]](#cite_note-Gnatta2013-23) Although acupuncture is generally considered a safe procedure, a 2013 review stated that the reports of infection transmission increased significantly in the prior decade, including those of mycobacterium. [[21]](#cite_note-Gnatta2013-23) Although it is recommended that practitioners of acupuncture use disposable needles, the reuse of sterilized needles is still permitted. [[21]](#cite_note-Gnatta2013-23) It is also recommended that thorough control practices for preventing infection be implemented and adapted. [[21]](#cite_note-Gnatta2013-23) English-language A 2013 systematic review of the English-language case reports found that serious adverse events associated with acupuncture are rare, but that acupuncture is not without risk. [[19]](#cite_note-Xu_S-21) Between 2000 and 2011 the English-language literature from 25 countries and regions reported 294 adverse events. [[19]](#cite_note-Xu_S-21) The majority of the reported adverse events were relatively minor, and the incidences were low. [[19]](#cite_note-Xu_S-21) For example, a prospective survey of 34,000 acupuncture treatments found no serious adverse events and 43 minor ones, a rate of 1.3 per 1000 interventions. [[19]](#cite_note-Xu_S-21) Another survey found there were 7.1% minor adverse events, of which 5 were serious, amid 97,733 acupuncture patients. [[19]](#cite_note-Xu_S-21) The most common adverse effect observed was infection (e.g. mycobacterium), and the majority of infections were bacterial in nature, caused by skin contact at the needling site. [[19]](#cite_note-Xu_S-21) Infection has also resulted from skin contact with unsterilized equipment or with dirty towels in an unhygienic clinical setting. [[19]](#cite_note-Xu_S-21) Other adverse complications included five reported cases of [spinal cord injuries](/wiki/Spinal_cord_injuries) (e.g. migrating broken needles or needling too deeply), four brain injuries, four peripheral nerve injuries, five [heart](/wiki/Heart) injuries, seven other organ and tissue injuries, bilateral [epithelioid technique. [[19]](#cite_note-Xu_S-21) Adverse reactions from acupuncture, which are unusual and uncommon in typical acupuncture practice, included needle migration. [[19]](#cite_note-Xu_S-21) A 2013 systematic review found 31 cases of vascular injuries caused by acupuncture, three causing death. [[93]](#cite_note-Bergqvist-96) Two died from pericardial tamponade and one was from an aortoduodenal fistula. [[93]](#cite_note-Bergqvist-96) The same review found vascular injuries were rare, bleeding and pseudoaneurysm were most prevalent. [[93]](#cite_note-Bergqvist-96) A 2011 systematic review (without restriction in time or language), aiming to summarize all reported case of [cardiac tamponade](/wiki/Cardiac_tamponade) after acupuncture, found 26 cases resulting in 14 deaths, with little doubt about cause in most fatal instances. [[94]](#cite_note-Ernst-Zhang-97) The same review concluded that cardiac tamponade was a serious, usually fatal, though theoretically avoidable complication following acupuncture, and urged training to minimize risk. [[94]](#cite_note-Ernst-Zhang-97) A 2012 review found that a number of adverse events were reported after acupuncture in the UK's [National Health Service](/wiki/National_Health_Service_(England)) (NHS), 95% of which were not severe, [[42]](#cite_note-Wheway2012-45) though miscategorization and under-reporting may alter the total figures. [[42]](#cite_note-Wheway2012-45) From January 2009 to December 2011, 468 safety incidents were recognized within the NHS organizations. [[42]](#cite_note-Wheway2012-45) The adverse events recorded included retained needles (31%), dizziness (30%), loss of consciousness/unresponsive (19%), falls (4%), bruising or soreness at needle site (2%), pneumothorax (1%) and other adverse side effects (12%). [[42]](#cite_note-Wheway2012-45) Acupuncture practitioners should know, and be prepared to be responsible for, any substantial harm from treatments. [[42]](#cite_note-Wheway2012-45) Some acupuncture proponents argue that the long history of acupuncture suggests it is safe. [[42]](#cite_note-Wheway2012-45) However, there is an increasing literature on adverse events (e.g. spinal-cord injury). [[42]](#cite_note-Wheway2012-45) Acupuncture seems to be safe in people getting [anticoagulants](/wiki/Anticoagulant), assuming needles are used at the correct location and depth, [[95]](#cite_note-Mcculloch2014-98) but studies are required to verify these findings. [[95]](#cite_note-Mcculloch2014-98) Chinese, Korean, and Japanese-language A 2010 systematic review of the Chinese-language literature found numerous acupuncture-related adverse events, including pneumothorax, fainting, [subarachnoid hemorrhage](/wiki/Subarachnoid_hemorrhage), and infection as the most frequent, and cardiovascular injuries, subarachnoid hemorrhage, pneumothorax, and recurrent cerebral hemorrhage as the most serious, most of which were due to improper technique. [[96]](#cite_note-Zhang-2010-99) Between 1980 and 2009, the Chinese-language literature reported 479 adverse events. [[96]](#cite_note-Zhang-2010-99) [Prospective surveys](/w/index.php?title=Prospective_survey&action=edit&redlink=1) show that mild, transient acupuncture-associated adverse events ranged from 6.71% to 15%. [[96]](#cite_note-Zhang-2010-99) In a study with 190,924 patients, the prevalence of serious adverse events was roughly 0.024%. [[96]](#cite_note-Zhang-2010-99) Another study showed a rate of adverse events requiring specific treatment of 2.2%, 4,963 [incidences](/wiki/Incidence_(epidemiology)) among 229,230 patients. [[96]](#cite_note-Zhang-2010-99) Infections, mainly [hepatitis](/wiki/Hepatitis), after acupuncture are reported often in English-language research, though are rarely reported in Chinese-language research, making it plausible that acupuncture-associated infections have been underreported in China. [[96]](#cite_note-Zhang-2010-99) Infections were mostly caused by poor sterilization of acupuncture needles. [[96]](#cite_note-Zhang-2010-99) Other adverse events included spinal epidural hematoma (in the cervical, thoracic and lumbar spine), chylothorax, injuries of abdominal organs and tissues, injuries in the neck region, injuries to the eyes, including orbital hemorrhage, traumatic cataract, injury of the oculomotor nerve and retinal puncture, hemorrhage to the cheeks and the hypoglottis, peripheral motor-nerve injuries and subsequent motor dysfunction, local allergic reactions to metal needles, stroke, and cerebral hemorrhage after acupuncture. [[96]](#cite_note-Zhang-2010-99) A causal link between acupuncture and the adverse events cardiac arrest, pyknolepsy, shock, fever, cough, thirst, aphonia, leg numbness, and sexual dysfunction remains uncertain. [[96]](#cite_note-Zhang-2010-99) The same review concluded that acupuncture can be considered inherently safe when practiced by properly trained practitioners, but the review also stated there is a need to find effective strategies to minimize the health risks. [[96]](#cite_note-Zhang-2010-99) Between 1999 and 2010, the Korean-language literature contained reports of 1104 adverse events. [[97]](#cite_note-100) Between the 1980s and 2002, the Japanese-language literature contained reports of 150 adverse events. [[98]](#cite_note-101) Children and pregnancy Although acupuncture has been practiced for thousands of years in China, its use in [pediatrics](/wiki/Pediatrics) in the United States did not become common until the early 2000s. In 2007, the [National Health Interview Survey](/wiki/National_Health_Interview_Survey) (NHIS) conducted by the [National Center For Health Statistics](/wiki/National_Center_for_Health_Statistics) (NCHS) estimated that approximately 150,000 children had received acupuncture treatment for a variety of conditions. [[99]](#cite_note-102) In 2008 a study determined that the use of acupuncture-needle treatment on children was "questionable" due to the possibility of adverse side-effects and the pain manifestation differences in children versus adults. The study also includes warnings against practicing acupuncture on infants, as well as on children who are over-fatigued, very weak, or have over-eaten. [[100]](#cite_note-103) When used on children, acupuncture is considered safe when administered by well-trained, licensed practitioners using sterile needles; however, a 2011 review found there was limited research to draw definite conclusions about the overall safety of pediatric acupuncture. [[3]](#cite_note-Adams_2011-5) The same review found 279 adverse events, 25 of them serious. [[3]](#cite_note-Adams_2011-5) The adverse events were mostly mild in nature (e.g. bruising or bleeding). [[3]](#cite_note-Adams_2011-5) The prevalence of mild adverse events ranged from 10.1% to 13.5%, an estimated 168 incidences among 1,422 patients. [[3]](#cite_note-Adams_2011-5) On rare occasions adverse events were serious (e.g. [cardiac rupture](/wiki/Cardiac_rupture) or [hemoptysis](/wiki/Hemoptysis)); many might have been a result of substandard practice. [[3]](#cite_note-Adams_2011-5) The incidence of serious adverse events was 5 per one million, which included children and adults. [[3]](#cite_note-Adams_2011-5) When used during pregnancy, the majority of adverse events caused by acupuncture were mild and transient, with few serious adverse events. [[101]](#cite_note-Park-2014-104) The most frequent mild adverse event was needling or unspecified pain, followed by bleeding. [[101]](#cite_note-Park-2014-104) Although two deaths (one stillbirth and one neonatal death) were reported, there was a lack of acupuncture-associated maternal mortality. [[101]](#cite_note-Park-2014-104) Limiting the evidence as certain, probable or possible in the causality evaluation, the estimated incidence of adverse events following acupuncture in pregnant women was 131 per 10,000. [[101]](#cite_note-Park-2014-104) Although acupuncture is not contraindicated in pregnant women, some specific acupuncture points are particularly sensitive to needle insertion; these spots, as well as the [abdominal region](/wiki/Abdomen), should be avoided during pregnancy. [[2]](#cite_note-Berman2010-4) Moxibustion and cupping Four adverse events associated with moxibustion were bruising, burns and cellulitis, spinal epidural abscess, and large superficial basal cell carcinoma. [[19]](#cite_note-Xu_S-21) Ten adverse events were associated with cupping. [[19]](#cite_note-Xu_S-21) The minor ones were [keloid](/wiki/Keloid) scarring, burns, and [bullae](/wiki/Bulla_(dermatology)); [[19]](#cite_note-Xu_S-21) the serious ones were acquired hemophilia A, stroke following cupping on the back and neck, factitious [panniculitis](/wiki/Panniculitis), reversible cardiac hypertrophy, and [iron deficiency anemia](/wiki/Iron_deficiency_anemia). [[19]](#cite_note-Xu_S-21) Risk of forgoing conventional medical care As with other alternative medicines, unethical or naïve practitioners may induce patients to exhaust financial resources by pursuing ineffective treatment. [[6]](#cite_note-Barrett2007-8) [[102]](#cite_note-105) Professional ethics codes set by accrediting organizations such as the [National Certification Commission for Acupuncture and Oriental Medicine](/wiki/National_Certification_Commission_for_Acupuncture_and_Oriental_Medicine) require practitioners to make "timely referrals to other health care professionals as may be appropriate." [[103]](#cite_note-NCCAOMethics-106) [Stephen Barrett](/wiki/Stephen_Barrett) states that there is a "risk that an acupuncturist whose approach to diagnosis is not based on scientific concepts will fail to diagnose a dangerous condition". [[104]](#cite_note-HumberAlmeder2013-107) Conceptual basis |Acupuncture| |Transcriptions| [Hanyu Pinyin](/wiki/Hanyu_Pinyin) Traditional a substantial part of [traditional Chinese medicine](/wiki/Traditional_Chinese_medicine) (TCM). Early acupuncture beliefs relied on concepts that are common in TCM, such as a life force energy called qi. [[105]](#cite_note-Aung11-108) Qi was believed to flow from the body's primary organs ( [zang-fu](/wiki/Zang-fu) organs) to the "superficial" body tissues of the skin, muscles, tendons, bones, and joints, through channels called meridians. [[106]](#cite_note-meridian-theory-109) Acupuncture points where needles are inserted are mainly (but not always) found at locations along the meridians. [[107]](#cite_note-Aung101-110) Acupuncture points not found along a meridian are called extraordinary points and those with no designated site are called "A-shi" points. [[107]](#cite_note-Aung101-110) In TCM, disease is generally perceived as a disharmony or imbalance in energies such as [yin, yang](/wiki/Traditional_Chinese_medicine#Yin_and_yang), [qi, xu, zàng-f, meridians](/wiki/Traditional_Chinese_medicine#Model_of_the_body), and of the interaction between the body and the environment. [[108]](#cite_note-111) Therapy is based on which "pattern of disharmony" can be identified. [[109]](#cite_note-112) [[110]](#cite_note-113) For example, some diseases are believed to be caused by meridians being invaded with an excess of wind, cold, and damp. [[111]](#cite_note-114) In order to determine which [pattern](/wiki/Traditional_chinese_medicine#Patterns) is at hand, practitioners examine things like the color and shape of the tongue, the relative strength of pulse-points, the smell of the breath, the quality of breathing, or the sound of the voice. [[112]](#cite_note-Tongue-115) [[113]](#cite_note-Maciocia-116) TCM and its concept of disease does not strongly differentiate between the cause and effect of symptoms. [[114]](#cite_note-117) Purported scientific basis Many within the [scientific community](/wiki/Scientific_community) consider attempts to rationalize acupuncture in science to be [quackery](/wiki/Quackery) and pseudoscience. [[7]](#cite_note-Wang2013-9) [[8]](#cite_note-rank-10) Academics "borderlands science" lying between science and pseudoscience. [[115]](#cite_note-Massimo2013-118) Rationalizations of traditional medicine It is a generally held belief within the acupuncture community that acupuncture points and meridians structures are special conduits for electrical signals, but no research has established any consistent anatomical structure or function for either acupuncture points or meridians. [[c]](#cite_note-SinghErnst2008-27) [[25]](#cite_note-Ahn2008-28) Human tests to determine whether electrical continuity was significantly different near meridians than other places in the body have been inconclusive. [[25]](#cite_note-Ahn2008-28) Scientific research has not supported the existence of qi, meridians, or yin and yang. [[c]](#cite_note-SinghErnst2008-27) [[25]](#cite_note-Ahn2008-28) [[26]](#cite_note-Mann2000-29) A [Nature](/wiki/Nature_(journal)) editorial described TCM as "fraught with pseudoscience", with the majority of its treatments having no logical [mechanism of action](/wiki/Mechanism_of_action). [[116]](#cite_note-swallow-119) [Quackwatch](/wiki/Quackwatch) states that "TCM theory and practice are not based upon the body of knowledge related to health, disease, and health care that has been widely accepted by the scientific community. TCM practitioners disagree among themselves about how to diagnose patients and which treatments should go with which diagnoses. Even if they could agree, the TCM theories are so nebulous that no amount of scientific study will enable TCM to offer rational care." [[6]](#cite_note-Barrett2007-8) Academic discussions of acupuncture still make reference to pseudoscientific concepts such as qi and meridians despite the lack of scientific evidence. [[117]](#cite_note-Ulett2002-120) Release of endorphins or adenosine Some modern practitioners support the use of acupuncture to treat pain, but have abandoned the use of qi, meridians, yin, yang and other mystical energies as an explanatory frameworks. [[9]](#cite_note-Peñas2010-11) [[26]](#cite_note-Mann2000-29) [[27]](#cite_note-Williams2013-30) The use of qi as an explanatory framework has been decreasing in China, even as it becomes more prominent during discussions of acupuncture in the US. [[117]](#cite_note-Ulett2002-120) Many acupuncturists attribute pain relief to the release of [endorphins](/wiki/Endorphins) when needles penetrate, but no longer support the idea that acupuncture can affect a disease. [[27]](#cite_note-Williams2013-30) [[117]](#cite_note-Ulett2002-120) Some studies suggest acupuncture causes a series of events within the [central nervous system](/wiki/Central_nervous_system), [[118]](#cite_note-Wang2008-121) and that it is possible to inhibit acupuncture's analgesic effects with the opioid antagonist [naloxone](/wiki/Naloxone). [[119]](#cite_note-122) Mechanical deformation of the skin by acupuncture needles appears to result in the release of [adenosine](/wiki/Adenosine). [[2]](#cite_note-Berman2010-4) The [anti-nociceptive](/wiki/Nociception) effect of acupuncture may be mediated by the [adenosine A1 receptor](/wiki/Adenosine_A1_receptor). [[120]](#cite_note-123) A 2014 review in Nature Reviews Cancer analyzed mouse studies that suggested acupuncture relieves pain via the local release of adenosine, which then triggered nearby A1 receptors. The review found that in those studies, because acupuncture "caused more tissue damage and inflammation relative to the size of the animal in mice than in humans, such studies unnecessarily muddled a finding that local inflammation can result in the local release of adenosine with analgesic effect." [[78]](#cite_note-Gorski2014-81) History Origins Acupuncture, along with [moxibustion](/wiki/Moxibustion), is one of the oldest practices of traditional Chinese medicine. [[30]](#cite_note-abc-33) Most historians believe the practice began in China, though there are some conflicting narratives on when it originated. [[28]](#cite_note-White-Ernst-31) [[31]](#cite_note-Porter_2013_p._403-34) Academics David Ramey and Paul Buell said the exact date acupuncture was founded depends on the extent to which dating of ancient texts can be trusted and the interpretation of what constitutes acupuncture. [[121]](#cite_note-Ramey-124) Acupressure therapy was prevalent in India. Once [Buddhism spread to China](/wiki/Chinese_Buddhism#Han_Dynasty_(206_BCE-220_CE)), the acupressure therapy was also integrated into common medical practice in China and it came to be known as acupuncture. The major points of Indian acupressure and Chinese acupuncture are similar to each other. [[122]](#cite_note-125) According to an article in Rheumatology, the first documentation of an "organized system of diagnosis and treatment" for acupuncture was in Inner Classic of Huang Di ( [Huangdi Neijing](/wiki/Huangdi_Neijing)) from about 100 BC. [[28]](#cite_note-White-Ernst-31) Gold and silver needles found in the tomb of [Liu Sheng](/wiki/Liu_Sheng,_Prince_of_Zhongshan) from around 100 BC are believed to be the earliest archaeological evidence of acupuncture, though it is unclear if that was their purpose. [[121]](#cite_note-Ramey-124) According to Plinio Prioreschi, the earliest known historical record of acupuncture is the [Shiji](/wiki/Shiji) ("Records of the Grand Historian"), written by a historian around 100 BC. [[29]](#cite_note-Prioreschi2004-32) It is believed that this text was documenting what was established practice at that time. [[28]](#cite_note-White-Ernst-31) Alternate theories The 5,000-year-old mummified body of [Ötzi the Iceman](/wiki/%C3%96tzi_the_Iceman) was found with 15 groups of tattoos, [[123]](#cite_note-Dorfer-1999-126) many of which were located at points on the body where acupuncture needles are used for abdominal or lower back problems. Evidence from the body suggests Ötzi had these conditions. [[31]](#cite_note-Porter_2013_p._403-34) This has been cited as evidence that practices similar to acupuncture may have been practised elsewhere in [Eurasia](/wiki/Eurasia) during the early [Bronze Age](/wiki/Bronze_Age); [[123]](#cite_note-Dorfer-1999-126) however, The Oxford Handbook of the History of Medicine calls this theory "speculative". [[32]](#cite_note-Jackson_2011_p._610-35) It is considered unlikely that acupuncture was practised before 2000 BC. [[121]](#cite_note-Ramey-124) Acupuncture may have been practised during the [Neolithic](/wiki/Neolithic) era, near the end of the [Stone Age](/wiki/Stone_Age), using sharpened stones called [Bian shi](/wiki/Bian_Stones). [[30]](#cite_note-abc-33): 70 Many Chinese texts from later eras refer to sharp stones called "plen", which means "stone probe", that may have been used for acupuncture purposes. [[30]](#cite_note-abc-33): 70 The ancient Chinese medical text, Huangdi Neijing, indicates that sharp stones were believed at-the-time to cure illnesses at or near the body's surface, perhaps because of the short depth a stone could penetrate. [[30]](#cite_note-abc-33): 71 However, it is more likely that stones were used for other medical purposes, such as puncturing a growth to drain its [pus](/wiki/Pus). [[28]](#cite_note-White-Ernst-31) [[31]](#cite_note-Porter_2013_p._403-34) The [Mawangdui](/wiki/Mawangdui) texts, which are believed to be from the 2nd century BC, mention the use of pointed stones to open [abscesses](/wiki/Abscess), and moxibustion, but not for acupuncture. [[29]](#cite_note-Prioreschi2004-32) It is also speculated that these stones may have been used for bloodletting, due to the ancient Chinese belief that illnesses were caused by demons within the body that could be killed or released. [[124]](#cite_note-Singh_Ernst_2008_p._42-127) It is likely bloodletting was an antecedent to acupuncture. [[31]](#cite_note-Porter_2013_p._403-34) According to historians [Lu Gwei-djen](/wiki/Lu_Gwei-djen) and [Joseph Needham](/wiki/Joseph_Needham), there is substantial evidence that acupuncture may have begun around 600 BC. [[30]](#cite_note-abc-33) Some hieroglyphs and [pictographs](/wiki/Pictogram) from that era suggests acupuncture and moxibustion were practised. [[125]](#cite_note-Robson-128) However, historians Lu and Needham said it was unlikely a needle could be made out of the materials available in China during this time period. [[30]](#cite_note-abc-33): 71-72 It is possible that [bronze](/wiki/Bronze) was used for early acupuncture needles. Tin, copper, gold and silver are also possibilities, though they are considered less likely, or to have been used in fewer cases. [[30]](#cite_note-abc-33): 69 If acupuncture was practised during the [Shang dynasty](/wiki/Shang_dynasty) (1766 to 1122 BC), organic materials like thorns, sharpened bones, or bamboo may have been used. [[30]](#cite_note-abc-33): 70 Once methods for producing steel were discovered, it would replace all other materials, since it could be used to create a very fine, but sturdy needles. [[30]](#cite_note-abc-33): 74 Lu and Needham noted that all the ancient materials that could have been used for acupuncture and which often produce archaeological evidence, such as sharpened bones, bamboo or stones, were also used for other purposes. [[30]](#cite_note-abc-33) An article in Rheumatology said that the absence of any mention of acupuncture in documents found in the tomb of [Mawangdui](/wiki/Mawangdui) from 198 BC suggest that acupuncture was not practised by that time. [[28]](#cite_note-White-Ernst-31) Belief systems Several different and sometimes conflicting belief systems emerged regarding acupuncture. This may have been the result of competing schools of thought. [[28]](#cite_note-White-Ernst-31) Some ancient texts referred to using acupuncture to cause bleeding, while others mixed the ideas of blood-letting and spiritual ch'i energy. Over time, the focus shifted from blood to the concept of puncturing specific points on the body, and eventually to balancing Yin and Yang energies as well. [[29]](#cite_note-Prioreschi2004-32) According to David Ramey, no single "method or theory" was ever predominantly adopted as the standard. [[126]](#cite_note-129) At the time, scientific knowledge of medicine was not yet developed, especially because in China dissection of the deceased was forbidden, preventing the development of basic anatomical knowledge. [[28]](#cite_note-White-Ernst-31) It is not certain when specific acupuncture points were introduced, but the autobiography of [Bian Que](/wiki/Bian_Que) from around 400-500 BC references inserting needles at designated areas. [[30]](#cite_note-abc-33) Bian Que believed there was a single acupuncture point at the top of one's skull that he called the point "of the hundred meetings." [[30]](#cite_note-abc-33): 83 Texts dated to be from 156-186 BC document early beliefs in channels of life force energy called meridians that would later be an element in early acupuncture beliefs. [[121]](#cite_note-Ramey-124) Ramey and Buell said the "practice and theoretical underpinnings" of modern acupuncture were introduced in The Yellow Emperor's Classic (Huangdi Neijing) around 100 BC. [[29]](#cite_note-Prioreschi2004-32) [[121]](#cite_note-Ramey-124) It introduced the concept of using acupuncture to manipulate the flow of life energy (qi) in a network of meridian (channels) in the body. [[121]](#cite_note-Ramey-124) [[127]](#cite_note-Epler-130) The network concept was made up of acu-tracts, such as a line down the arms, where it said acupoints were located. Some of the sites acupuncturists use needles at today still have the same names as those given to them by the Yellow Emperor's Classic. [[30]](#cite_note-abc-33): 93 Numerous additional documents were published over the centuries introducing new acupoints. [[30]](#cite_note-abc-33): 101 By the 4th century AD, most of the acupuncture sites in use today had been named and identified. [[30]](#cite_note-abc-33): 101 Early development in China Establishment and growth In the first half of the 1st century AD, acupuncturists began promoting the belief that acupuncture's effectiveness was influenced by the time of day or night, the lunar cycle, and the season. [[30]](#cite_note-abc-33): 140-41 [[d]](#cite_note-131)) was a set of beliefs that curing diseases relied on the alignment of both heavenly (tian) and earthly (di) forces that were attuned to cycles like that of the sun and moon. [[30]](#cite_note-abc-33): 140-41 There were several different belief systems that relied on a number of celestial and earthly bodies or elements that rotated and only became aligned at certain times. [[30]](#cite_note-abc-33): 140-41 According to Needham and Lu, these "arbitrary predictions" were depicted by acupuncturists in complex charts and through a set of special terminology. [[30]](#cite_note-abc-33) Acupuncture needles during this period were much thicker than most modern ones and often resulted in infection. Infection is caused by a lack of sterilization, but at that time it was believed to be caused by use of the wrong needle, or needling in the wrong place, or at the wrong time. [[30]](#cite_note-abc-33): 102-03 Later, many needles were heated in boiling water, or in a flame. Sometimes needles were used while they were still hot, creating a [cauterizing](/wiki/Cauterizing) effect at the injection site. [[30]](#cite_note-abc-33): 104 Nine needles were recommended in the Great Compendium of Acupuncture and Moxibustion [[e]](#cite_note-132) from 1601, which may have been because of an ancient Chinese belief that nine was a magic number. [[30]](#cite_note-abc-33): 102-03 Other belief systems were based on the idea that the human body operated on a rhythm and acupuncture had to be applied at the right point in the rhythm to be effective. [[30]](#cite_note-abc-33): 140-41 In some cases a lack of balance between Yin and Yang were believed to be the cause of disease. [[30]](#cite_note-abc-33): 140-41 In the 1st century AD, many of the first books about acupuncture were published and recognized acupuncturist experts began to emerge. The Zhen Jiu Jia Yi Jing, [[f]](#cite_note-133) which was published in the mid-3rd century, became the oldest acupuncture book that is still in existence in the modern era. [[30]](#cite_note-abc-33) Other books like the Yu Gui Zhen Jing, [[g]](#cite_note-134) written by the Director of Medical Services for China, were also influential during this period, but were not preserved. [[30]](#cite_note-abc-33) In the mid 7th century, [Sun Simiao](/wiki/Sun_Simiao) published acupuncture-related diagrams and charts that established standardized methods for finding acupuncture sites on people of different sizes and categorized acupuncture sites in a set of modules. [[30]](#cite_note-abc-33) Acupuncture became more established in China as improvements in paper led to the publication of more acupuncture books. [[128]](#cite_note-135) The Imperial Medical Service and the Imperial Medical College, which both supported acupuncture, became more established and created medical colleges in every province. [[30]](#cite_note-abc-33): 129 The public was also exposed to stories about royal figures being cured of their diseases by prominent acupuncturists. [[30]](#cite_note-abc-33): 129-35 By time the Great Compendium of Acupuncture and Moxibustion was published during the [Ming dynasty](/wiki/Ming_dynasty) (1368-1644 AD), most of the acupuncture practices used in the modern era had been established. [[28]](#cite_note-White-Ernst-31) Decline By the end of the Song dynasty (1279 AD), acupuncture had lost much of its status in China. [[129]](#cite_note-Barnes2005-136): 25 It became rarer in the following centuries, and was associated with less prestigious professions like [alchemy](/wiki/Alchemy), [shamanism](/wiki/Shamanism), [midwifery](/wiki/Midwifery) and moxibustion. [[129]](#cite_note-Barnes2005-136): 25 Additionally, by the 18th century, scientific rationality was becoming more popular than traditional superstitious beliefs. [[28]](#cite_note-White-Ernst-31) By 1757 a book documenting the history of Chinese medicine called acupuncture a "lost art". [[30]](#cite_note-abc-33): 160 Its decline was attributed in part to the popularity of prescriptions and medications, as well as its association with the lower classes. [[129]](#cite_note-Barnes2005-136): 188 In 1822, the Chinese Emperor signed a decree excluding the practice of acupuncture from the Imperial Medical Institute. [[28]](#cite_note-White-Ernst-31) He said it was unfit for practice by gentlemen-scholars. [[129]](#cite_note-Barnes2005-136): 308 In China acupuncture was increasingly associated with lower-class, illiterate practitioners. [[129]](#cite_note-Barnes2005-136): 58 It was restored for a time, but banned again in 1929 in favor of science-based Western medicine. Although acupuncture declined in China during this time period, it was also growing in popularity in other countries. [[31]](#cite_note-Porter_2013_p._403-34) International expansion Korea is believed to be the first country in Asia that acupuncture spread to outside of China. [[30]](#cite_note-abc-33) Within Korea there is a legend that acupuncture was developed by emperor [Dangun](/wiki/Dangun), though it is more likely to have been brought into Korea from a Chinese colonial prefecture in 514 AD. [[30]](#cite_note-abc-33): 262-63 Acupuncture use was commonplace in Korea by the 6th century. It spread to Vietnam in the 8th and 9th centuries. [[31]](#cite_note-Porter_2013_p._403-34) As Vietnam began trading with Japan and China around the 9th century, it was influenced by their acupuncture practices as well. [[28]](#cite_note-White-Ernst-31) China and Korea sent "medical missionaries" that spread traditional Chinese medicine to Japan, starting around 219 AD. In 553, several Korean and Chinese citizens were appointed to re-organize medical education in Japan and they incorporated acupuncture as part of that system. [[30]](#cite_note-abc-33): 264 Japan later sent students back to China and established acupuncture as one of five divisions of the Chinese State Medical Administration System. [[30]](#cite_note-abc-33): 264-65 Acupuncture began to spread to Europe in the second half of the 17th century. Around this time the surgeon-general of the [Dutch East India Company](/wiki/Dutch_East_India_Company) met Japanese and Chinese acupuncture practitioners and later encouraged Europeans to further investigate it. [[30]](#cite_note-abc-33): 264-65 He published the first in-depth description of acupuncture for the European audience and created the term "acupuncture" in his 1683 work De Acupunctura. [[124]](#cite_note-Singh_Ernst_2008_p._42-127) France was an early adopter among the West due to the influence of Jesuit missionaries, who brought the practice to French clinics in the 16th century. [[28]](#cite_note-White-Ernst-31) The French doctor Louis Berlioz (the father of the composer [Hector Berlioz](/wiki/Hector_Berlioz)) is usually credited with being the first to experiment with the procedure in Europe in 1810, before publishing his findings in 1816. [[129]](#cite_note-Barnes2005-136): 308 By the 19th century, acupuncture had become commonplace in many areas of the world. [[30]](#cite_note-abc-33): 295 Americans and Britons began showing interest in acupuncture in the early 19th century, although interest waned by mid-century. [[28]](#cite_note-White-Ernst-31) Western practitioners abandoned acupuncture's traditional beliefs in spiritual energy, [pulse diagnosis](/wiki/Pulse_diagnosis), and the cycles of the moon, sun or the body's rhythm. Diagrams of the flow of spiritual energy, for example, conflicted with the West's own anatomical diagrams. It adopted a new set of ideas for acupuncture based on tapping needles into nerves. [[28]](#cite_note-White-Ernst-31) [[31]](#cite_note-Porter_2013_p._403-34) [[32]](#cite_note-Jackson_2011_p._610-35) In Europe it was speculated that acupuncture may allow or prevent the flow of electricity in the body, as electrical pulses were found to make a frog's leg twitch after death. [[124]](#cite_note-Singh_Ernst_2008_p._42-127) The West eventually created a belief system based on Travell trigger points that were believed to inhibit pain. They were in the same locations as China's spiritually identified acupuncture points, but under a different nomenclature. [[28]](#cite_note-White-Ernst-31) The first elaborate Western treatise on acupuncture was published in 1683 by [Willem ten Rhijne](/wiki/Willem_ten_Rhijne). [[129]](#cite_note-Barnes2005-136): 75 Modern era In China, the popularity of acupuncture rebounded in 1949 when [Mao Zedong](/wiki/Mao_Zedong) took power and sought to unite China behind traditional cultural values. It was also during this time that many Eastern medical practices were consolidated under the name traditional Chinese medicine (TCM). [[31]](#cite_note-Porter_2013_p._403-34) New practices were adopted in the 20th century, such as using a cluster of needles, [[30]](#cite_note-abc-33): 164 electrified needles, or leaving needles inserted for up to a week. [[30]](#cite_note-abc-33): 164 A lot of emphasis developed on using [acupuncture on the ear](/wiki/Auriculotherapy). [[30]](#cite_note-abc-33): 164 Acupuncture research organizations such as the [International Society of Acupuncture](/wiki/International_Society_of_Acupuncture) were founded in the 1940s and 1950s and acupuncture services became available in modern hospitals. [[28]](#cite_note-White-Ernst-31) [[130]](#cite_note-137) China, where acupuncture was believed to have originated, was increasingly influenced by Western medicine. [[28]](#cite_note-White-Ernst-31) Meanwhile, acupuncture grew in popularity in the US. The US Congress created the Office of Alternative Medicine in 1992 and the [National Institutes of Health](/wiki/National_Institutes_of_Health) (NIH) declared support for acupuncture for some conditions in November 1997. In 1999, the [National Center for Complementary and Alternative Medicine](/wiki/National_Center_for_Complementary_and_Integrative_Health) was created within the NIH. Acupuncture became the most popular alternative medicine in the US. [[118]](#cite_note-Wang2008-121) Politicians from the [Chinese Communist Party](/wiki/Chinese_Communist_Party) said acupuncture was superstitious and conflicted with the party's commitment to science. [[131]](#cite_note-Crozier1968-138) Communist Party Chairman Mao Zedong later reversed this position, [[131]](#cite_note-Crozier1968-138) arguing that the practice was based on scientific principles. [[132]](#cite_note-Taylor2011-139) In 1971, New York Times reporter [James Reston](/wiki/James_Reston) published an article on his acupuncture experiences in China, which led to more investigation of and support for acupuncture. [[28]](#cite_note-White-Ernst-31) The US President [Richard Nixon visited China in 1972](/wiki/1972_Nixon_visit_to_China). [[133]](#cite_note-CSICOP-140) During one part of the visit, the delegation was shown a patient undergoing major surgery while fully awake, ostensibly receiving acupuncture rather than [anesthesia](/wiki/Anesthesia). [[133]](#cite_note-CSICOP-140) Later it was found that the patients selected for the surgery had both a high [pain tolerance](/wiki/Pain_tolerance) and received heavy indoctrination before the operation; these demonstration cases were also frequently receiving [morphine](/wiki/Morphine) surreptitiously through an [intravenous drip](/wiki/Intravenous_therapy) that observers were told contained only fluids and nutrients. [[133]](#cite_note-CSICOP-140) One patient receiving [open heart surgery](/wiki/Open_heart_surgery) while awake was ultimately found to have received a combination of three powerful sedatives as well as large injections of a [local anesthetic](/wiki/Local_anesthetic) into the wound. [[58]](#cite_note-Colquhoun2013-61) After the [National Institute of Health](/wiki/National_Institute_of_Health) expressed support for acupuncture for a limited number of conditions, adoption in the US grew further. [[28]](#cite_note-White-Ernst-31) In 1972 the first legal acupuncture center in the US was established in Washington DC [[134]](#cite_note-JCIM_Lee-141) and in 1973 the American [Internal Revenue Service](/wiki/Internal_Revenue_Service) allowed acupuncture to be deducted as a medical expense. [[135]](#cite_note-'70s_133-142) In 2006, a [BBC](/wiki/BBC) documentary Alternative Medicine filmed a patient undergoing open heart surgery allegedly under acupuncture-induced anesthesia. It was later revealed that the patient had been given a cocktail of anesthetics. [[136]](#cite_note-SinghGuardian-143) [[137]](#cite_note-SinghTelegraph-144) In 2010, [UNESCO](/wiki/UNESCO) inscribed "acupuncture and [moxibustion](/wiki/Moxibustion) of traditional Chinese medicine" on the [UNESCO Intangible Cultural Heritage List](/wiki/UNESCO_Intangible_Cultural_Heritage_Lists) following China's nomination. [[138]](#cite_note-unes_Acup-145) Adoption Acupuncture is most heavily practiced in China [[96]](#cite_note-Zhang-2010-99) and is popular in [[96]](#cite_note-Zhang-2010-99) the US, [[19]](#cite_note-Xu_S-21) Australia, [[139]](#cite_note-dahfdfaDF-146) and Europe. [[140]](#cite_note-Ramsay2009-147) In Switzerland, acupuncture has become the most frequently used alternative medicine since 2004. [[141]](#cite_note-148) In the United Kingdom, a total of 4 million acupuncture treatments were administered in 2009. [[142]](#cite_note-149) Acupuncture is used in most pain clinics and hospices in the UK. [[41]](#cite_note-NHS-44) An estimated 1 in 10 adults in Australia used acupuncture in 2004. [[139]](#cite_note-dahfdfaDF-146) In Japan, it is estimated that 25 percent of the population will try acupuncture at some point, [[143]](#cite_note-Ishizaki2010-150) though in most cases it is not covered by [public health insurance](/wiki/Health_care_system_in_Japan). [[143]](#cite_note-Ishizaki2010-150) Users of acupuncture in Japan are more likely to be elderly and to have a limited education. [[143]](#cite_note-Ishizaki2010-150) Approximately half of users surveyed indicated a likelihood to seek such remedies in the future, while 37% did not. [[143]](#cite_note-Ishizaki2010-150) Less than one percent of the US population reported having used acupuncture in the early 1990s. [[144]](#cite_note-Samadi2012-151) By the early 2010s, more than 14 million Americans reported having used acupuncture as part of their health care. [[144]](#cite_note-Samadi2012-151) In the US, acupuncture is increasingly (as of 2014 [[update]](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Acupuncture&action=edit)) used at [academic medical centers](/wiki/Academic_medical_centers), [[78]](#cite_note-Gorski2014-81) and is usually offered through CAM centers or anesthesia and pain management services. Examples include those at guidelines](/wiki/Clinical_practice_guideline) from 2022 list acupuncture among the types of complementary and alternative medicines physicians should consider in preference to [opioid](/wiki/Opioid) prescription for certain kinds of pain. [[146]](#cite_note-153) The use of acupuncture in Germany increased by 20% in 2007, after the [German acupuncture trials](/wiki/German_acupuncture_trials) supported its efficacy for certain uses. [[147]](#cite_note-accupuncture-rponline-154) In 2011, there were more than one million users, [[147]](#cite_note-accupuncture-rponline-154) and insurance companies have estimated that two-thirds of German users are women. [[147]](#cite_note-accupuncture-rponline-154) As a result of the trials, German [public health insurers](/wiki/Publicly_funded_health_care) began to cover acupuncture for chronic low back pain and osteoarthritis of the knee, but not tension headache or migraine. [[148]](#cite_note-Birch2007-155) This decision was based in part on [socio-political](/wiki/Socio-political) reasons. [[148]](#cite_note-Birch2007-155) Some insurers in Germany chose to stop reimbursement of acupuncture because of the trials. [[149]](#cite_note-He2013-156) For other conditions, insurers in Germany were not convinced that acupuncture had adequate benefits over usual care or sham treatments. [[150]](#cite_note-Porter2013-157) Highlighting the results of the placebo group, researchers refused to accept a placebo therapy as efficient. [[151]](#cite_note-Hinrichs-158) Regulation There are various government and trade association regulatory bodies for acupuncture in the United Kingdom, the United States, Saudi Arabia, Australia, New Zealand, Japan, Canada, and in European countries and elsewhere. The [World Health Organization](/wiki/World_Health_Organization) recommends that before being licensed or certified, an acupuncturist receive 200 hours of specialized training if they are a physician and 2,500 hours for non-physicians; many governments have adopted similar standards. In Hong Kong, the practice of acupuncture is regulated by the Chinese Medicine Council that was formed in 1999 by the Legislative Council. It includes a licensing exam and registration, as well as degree courses approved by the board. [[152]](#cite_note-159) Canada has acupuncture licensing programs in the provinces of British Columbia, Ontario, Alberta and Quebec; standards set by the Chinese Medicine and Acupuncture Association of Canada are used in provinces without government regulation. [[140]](#cite_note-Ramsay2009-147) Regulation in the US began in the 1970s in California, which was eventually followed by every state but Wyoming and Idaho. Licensing requirements vary greatly from state to state. The needles used in acupuncture are regulated in the US by the [Food and Drug Administration](/wiki/Food_and_Drug_Administration). [[153]](#cite_note-ChanLee2001-160) In some states acupuncture is regulated by a board of medical examiners, while in others by the board of licensing, health or education. In Japan, acupuncturists are licensed by the [Minister of Health, Labour and Welfare](/wiki/Ministry_of_Health,_Labour,_and_Welfare) after passing an examination and graduating from a technical school or university. [[154]](#cite_note-:0-161) In Australia, the Chinese Medicine Board of Australia regulates acupuncture, among other Chinese medical traditions, and restricts the use of titles like 'acupuncturist' to registered practitioners only. [[155]](#cite_note-162) The practice of Acupuncture in New Zealand in 1990 acupuncture was included into the Governmental [Accident Compensation Corporation](/wiki/Accident_Compensation_Corporation) (ACC) Act. This inclusion granted qualified and professionally registered acupuncturists to provide subsidised care and treatment to citizens, residents, and temporary visitors for work or sports related injuries that occurred within the country of New Zealand. The two bodies for the regulation of acupuncture and attainment of ACC treatment provider status in New Zealand are Acupuncture NZ, [[156]](#cite_note-163) and The New Zealand Acupuncture Standards Authority. [[157]](#cite_note-164) [[158]](#cite_note-165) At least 28 countries in Europe have professional associations for acupuncturists. [[154]](#cite_note-:0-161) In France, the [Académie Nationale de Médecine](/wiki/Acad%C3%A9mie_Nationale_de_M%C3%A9decine) (National Academy of Medicine) has regulated acupuncture since 1955.
